notable_for: New Deal
Leading the US through the Great Depression and World War II
Only U.S. president elected to four terms
Franklin D. Roosevelt.biography: Franklin D. Roosevelt, commonly known as FDR, was an American politician who served as the 32nd president of the United States from 1933 until his death in 1945. He directed the federal government during most of the Great Depression, implementing the New Deal to provide relief, recovery, and reform, and he led the country during the majority of World War II.

notable_for: Leadership in the American Civil Rights Movement
Advocacy of nonviolent resistance
Famous 'I Have a Dream' speech
Martin Luther King Jr..biography: Martin Luther King Jr. was an American Baptist minister and activist who became the most visible leader in the civil rights movement from 1955 until his assassination in 1968. He promoted nonviolent civil disobedience to combat racial segregation and injustice, drawing inspiration from Christian teachings and the nonviolent philosophy of Mahatma Gandhi.

notable_for: First human to walk on the Moon
Commander of Apollo 11
Work as an aerospace engineer and professor
Neil Armstrong.biography: Neil Armstrong was an American astronaut and aerospace engineer who became the first person to walk on the Moon on July 20, 1969, during NASA's Apollo 11 mission. Before joining the space program, he served as a naval aviator and test pilot. After his historic moonwalk, Armstrong continued to contribute to aerospace research and education.

notable_for: Leading the struggle against apartheid in South Africa
First black president of South Africa
Nobel Peace Prize laureate (1993)
Nelson Mandela.biography: Nelson Mandela was a South African anti-apartheid activist who spent 27 years in prison for his opposition to racial segregation. After his release, he played a key role in negotiating the end of apartheid and became South Africa's first black president in 1994. Mandela became a global symbol of reconciliation, justice, and forgiveness.

notable_for: Leading the Indian independence movement against British rule
Developing the philosophy of nonviolent resistance (Satyagraha)
Inspiring civil rights movements worldwide
Mahatma Gandhi.biography: Mahatma Gandhi was an Indian lawyer and political leader who pioneered nonviolent resistance to oppose British colonial rule. Through mass civil disobedience campaigns, boycotts, and marches, he mobilized millions of Indians. His ideas influenced later civil rights movements, including those led by Martin Luther King Jr. and Nelson Mandela.

notable_for: Theory of relativity
Contributions to quantum mechanics
Nobel Prize in Physics (1921)
Albert Einstein.biography: Albert Einstein was a German-born theoretical physicist whose work revolutionized modern physics. His theory of relativity changed the understanding of space, time, and gravity, while his contributions to quantum theory helped shape atomic and subatomic physics. Beyond science, Einstein was known for his humanism and philosophical reflections on peace, education, and creativity.

notable_for: Leading the US during the Civil War
Emancipation Proclamation
Defending the idea of government 'of the people, by the people, for the people'
Abraham Lincoln.biography: Abraham Lincoln was an American lawyer and statesman who served as the 16th president of the United States from 1861 until his assassination in 1865. He steered the country through the Civil War, preserved the Union, and worked to abolish slavery, issuing the Emancipation Proclamation and promoting the Thirteenth Amendment.

notable_for: Prime Minister of the United Kingdom during World War II
Inspirational wartime speeches
Nobel Prize in Literature (1953)
Winston Churchill.biography: Winston Churchill was a British politician and writer best known for his leadership of the United Kingdom during World War II. His speeches and radio broadcasts helped sustain British morale during the darkest moments of the war. He later received the Nobel Prize in Literature for his historical writings and oratory.

notable_for: Foundational works in logic, ethics, and metaphysics
Tutor to Alexander the Great
Influence on Western philosophy and science
Aristotle.biography: Aristotle was an ancient Greek philosopher and student of Plato who made enduring contributions to many fields, including logic, ethics, politics, biology, and metaphysics. His works shaped Western intellectual history for centuries and provided systematic frameworks for understanding knowledge, virtue, and the natural world.

Confucius.era: Spring and Autumn period of Chinese history
notable_for: Developing Confucianism
Emphasis on morality, social harmony, and proper conduct
Profound influence on East Asian culture and ethics
Confucius.biography: Confucius was a Chinese philosopher and teacher whose ideas centered on moral virtue, proper relationships, and social harmony. His teachings, later compiled in the Analects, became the foundation of Confucianism and deeply influenced Chinese and East Asian culture, education, and governance.

notable_for: Pioneering research on radioactivity
Discovery of polonium and radium
First person to win two Nobel Prizes in different sciences
Marie Curie.biography: Marie Curie was a Polish-born physicist and chemist who conducted groundbreaking research on radioactivity. She discovered the elements polonium and radium, shared the 1903 Nobel Prize in Physics with Pierre Curie and Henri Becquerel, and later received the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1911. Her work laid the foundation for nuclear physics and medical radiology.

Leonardo da Vinci.full_name: Leonardo di ser Piero da Vinci
notable_for: Masterpieces like the Mona Lisa and The Last Supper
Innovative anatomical and scientific studies
Designs for machines far ahead of his time
Leonardo da Vinci.biography: Leonardo da Vinci was an Italian polymath whose interests spanned painting, anatomy, engineering, architecture, and science. Considered one of the greatest artists of all time, he also filled notebooks with observations and sketches exploring human anatomy, flight, mechanics, and nature.

notable_for: Laws of motion and universal gravitation
Development of calculus (independently of Leibniz)
Foundational work in optics
Isaac Newton.biography: Isaac Newton was an English mathematician and physicist whose work laid the foundations for classical mechanics. His laws of motion and universal gravitation described the behavior of objects on Earth and in space. Newton also made major contributions to optics and mathematics, including early developments in calculus.

notable_for: Inventions such as the practical electric light bulb and phonograph
Founding industrial research laboratories
Holding over 1,000 patents
Thomas Edison.biography: Thomas Edison was an American inventor and entrepreneur renowned for developing practical electric lighting, sound recording, and motion picture technologies. He built one of the first industrial research labs and played a key role in shaping the modern technological and industrial landscape.

Eleanor Roosevelt.occupation: First Lady of the United States, diplomat, activist
notable_for: Advocacy for human rights and social justice
Role in drafting the Universal Declaration of Human Rights
Redefining the role of First Lady
Eleanor Roosevelt.biography: Eleanor Roosevelt was an American political figure, diplomat, and activist who transformed the role of First Lady by actively engaging in politics and social issues. After Franklin D. Roosevelt's death, she continued her work as a delegate to the United Nations, where she helped draft the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
